The `n`th elementary symmetric function evaluated at the elements of `s`

type: {R : Type u_1} → [inst : CommSemiring R] → Multiset R → ℕ → R
name: Multiset.esymm
docString: The `n`th elementary symmetric function evaluated at the elements of `s`

For any commutative semiring R and multiset s of type R, the k-th coefficient of the polynomial product of X + λ over λ in s equals the (cardinality of s - k)-th elementary symmetric function of s, provided that k is less than or equal to the cardinality of s.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommSemiring R] (s : Multiset R) {k : ℕ},
  k ≤ Multiset.card s →
    (Multiset.map (fun r => Polynomial.X + Polynomial.C r) s).prod.coeff k = s.esymm (Multiset.card s - k)
name: Multiset.prod_X_add_C_coeff
docString: For any commutative semiring R and multiset s of type R, the k-th coefficient of the polynomial product of X + λ over λ in s equals the (cardinality of s - k)-th elementary symmetric function of s, provided that k is less than or equal to the cardinality of s.

This theorem states that, for any index type `ι`, any function `f` from `ι` to the extended nonnegative real numbers (`ENNReal`), and any extended nonnegative real number `a`, the product of `a` and the indexed supremum (`iSup`) of `f` is equal to the supremum (denoted by `⨆ i`) of `a` times `f i` across all `i` in `ι`. In other words, multiplication distributes over the supremum in the extended nonnegative real numbers.

type: ∀ {ι : Sort u_4} {f : ι → ENNReal} {a : ENNReal}, a * iSup f = ⨆ i, a * f i
name: ENNReal.mul_iSup
docString: This theorem states that, for any index type `ι`, any function `f` from `ι` to the extended nonnegative real numbers (`ENNReal`), and any extended nonnegative real number `a`, the product of `a` and the indexed supremum (`iSup`) of `f` is equal to the supremum (denoted by `⨆ i`) of `a` times `f i` across all `i` in `ι`. In other words, multiplication distributes over the supremum in the extended nonnegative real numbers.

Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$.

type:
∀ {A : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Algebra ℚ A] (n : ℕ),
  (Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => PowerSeries.exp A ^ k) =
    PowerSeries.mk fun p => Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => ↑k ^ p * (algebraMap ℚ A) (↑(Nat.factorial p))⁻¹
name: PowerSeries.exp_pow_sum
docString:
Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$.

For two monovarying functions `f` and `g` over a finite set `s`, the product of their sums obeys the inequality $|s| \cdot \sum_{i \in s} f(i)g(i) \geq \left(\sum_{i \in s} f(i)\right) \cdot \left(\sum_{i \in s} g(i)\right)$.

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {α : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrderedRing α] {s : Finset ι} {f g : ι → α},
  MonovaryOn f g ↑s → ((s.sum fun i => f i) * s.sum fun i => g i) ≤ ↑s.card * s.sum fun i => f i * g i
name: MonovaryOn.sum_mul_sum_le_card_mul_sum
docString: For two monovarying functions `f` and `g` over a finite set `s`, the product of their sums obeys the inequality $|s| \cdot \sum_{i \in s} f(i)g(i) \geq \left(\sum_{i \in s} f(i)\right) \cdot \left(\sum_{i \in s} g(i)\right)$.

This theorem states that for a finite set `s` of some type `α` and an element `a` of type `α` that is not in `s`, along with a function `f` from `α` to another type `M` with a commutative monoid structure, the total product of `f(i)` for each `i` in the set obtained by inserting `a` into `s` equals the product of `f(a)` and the total product of `f(i)` for each `i` in `s`. In mathematical notation, this can be written as \(\prod_{i \in s \cup \{a\}} f(i) = f(a) \prod_{i \in s} f(i)\), assuming that the product is defined as `1` for an empty set.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Type u_5} [inst : CommMonoid M] {a : α} {s : Set α} (f : α → M),
  a ∉ s → s.Finite → (finprod fun i => finprod fun h => f i) = f a * finprod fun i => finprod fun h => f i
name: finprod_mem_insert
docString: This theorem states that for a finite set `s` of some type `α` and an element `a` of type `α` that is not in `s`, along with a function `f` from `α` to another type `M` with a commutative monoid structure, the total product of `f(i)` for each `i` in the set obtained by inserting `a` into `s` equals the product of `f(a)` and the total product of `f(i)` for each `i` in `s`. In mathematical notation, this can be written as \(\prod_{i \in s \cup \{a\}} f(i) = f(a) \prod_{i \in s} f(i)\), assuming that the product is defined as `1` for an empty set.

The sequence with `n`-th term `n ^ s * n! / (s * (s + 1) * ... * (s + n))`, for real `s`. We
will show that this tends to `Γ(s)` as `n → ∞`.

type: ℝ → ℕ → ℝ
name: Real.GammaSeq
docString:
The sequence with `n`-th term `n ^ s * n! / (s * (s + 1) * ... * (s + n))`, for real `s`. We
will show that this tends to `Γ(s)` as `n → ∞`.

Consider a series of functions `∑' i, f i x`. Assume that each individual function `f i` is of
class `C^N`, and moreover there is a uniform summable upper bound on the `k`-th derivative
for each `k ≤ N`. Then the series is also `C^N`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {𝕜 : Type u_3} {E : Type u_4} {F : Type u_5} [inst : IsROrC 𝕜] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : CompleteSpace F] [inst_5 : NormedSpace 𝕜 F]
  {f : α → E → F} {v : ℕ → α → ℝ} {N : ℕ∞},
  (∀ (i : α), ContDiff 𝕜 N (f i)) →
    (∀ (k : ℕ), ↑k ≤ N → Summable (v k)) →
      (∀ (k : ℕ) (i : α) (x : E), ↑k ≤ N → ‖iteratedFDeriv 𝕜 k (f i) x‖ ≤ v k i) →
        ContDiff 𝕜 N fun x => ∑' (i : α), f i x
name: contDiff_tsum
docString:
Consider a series of functions `∑' i, f i x`. Assume that each individual function `f i` is of
class `C^N`, and moreover there is a uniform summable upper bound on the `k`-th derivative
for each `k ≤ N`. Then the series is also `C^N`.

Consider a series of functions `∑' i, f i x`. Assume that each individual function `f i` is of
class `C^N`, and moreover there is a uniform summable upper bound on the `k`-th derivative
for each `k ≤ N` (except maybe for finitely many `i`s). Then the series is also `C^N`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {𝕜 : Type u_3} {E : Type u_4} {F : Type u_5} [inst : IsROrC 𝕜] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : CompleteSpace F] [inst_5 : NormedSpace 𝕜 F]
  {f : α → E → F} {v : ℕ → α → ℝ} {N : ℕ∞},
  (∀ (i : α), ContDiff 𝕜 N (f i)) →
    (∀ (k : ℕ), ↑k ≤ N → Summable (v k)) →
      (∀ (k : ℕ), ↑k ≤ N → ∀ᶠ (i : α) in Filter.cofinite, ∀ (x : E), ‖iteratedFDeriv 𝕜 k (f i) x‖ ≤ v k i) →
        ContDiff 𝕜 N fun x => ∑' (i : α), f i x
name: contDiff_tsum_of_eventually
docString:
Consider a series of functions `∑' i, f i x`. Assume that each individual function `f i` is of
class `C^N`, and moreover there is a uniform summable upper bound on the `k`-th derivative
for each `k ≤ N` (except maybe for finitely many `i`s). Then the series is also `C^N`.

If a function `f` equals `1` on a set `s`, then the product of `f i` over `i ∈ s` equals `1`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Type u_5} [inst : CommMonoid M] {f : α → M} {s : Set α},
  Set.EqOn f 1 s → (finprod fun i => finprod fun h => f i) = 1
name: finprod_mem_of_eqOn_one
docString: If a function `f` equals `1` on a set `s`, then the product of `f i` over `i ∈ s` equals `1`.

`σ k n` is the sum of the `k`th powers of the divisors of `n`

type: Lean.ParserDescr
name: Nat.ArithmeticFunction.termσ
docString: `σ k n` is the sum of the `k`th powers of the divisors of `n`

If `a` does not belong to the finset `s`, then the `n`th symmetric power of `{a} ∪ s` is
in 1-1 correspondence with the disjoint union of the `n - i`th symmetric powers of `s`,
for `0 ≤ i ≤ n`.

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  [inst : DecidableEq α] →
    {s : Finset α} →
      {a : α} →
        {n : ℕ} →
          a ∉ s → { x // x ∈ Finset.sym (insert a s) n } ≃ (i : Fin (n + 1)) × { x // x ∈ Finset.sym s (n - ↑i) }
name: Finset.symInsertEquiv
docString:
If `a` does not belong to the finset `s`, then the `n`th symmetric power of `{a} ∪ s` is
in 1-1 correspondence with the disjoint union of the `n - i`th symmetric powers of `s`,
for `0 ≤ i ≤ n`.

The sequence with `n`-th term `n ^ s * n! / (s * (s + 1) * ... * (s + n))`, for complex `s`.
We will show that this tends to `Γ(s)` as `n → ∞`.

type: ℂ → ℕ → ℂ
name: Complex.GammaSeq
docString:
The sequence with `n`-th term `n ^ s * n! / (s * (s + 1) * ... * (s + n))`, for complex `s`.
We will show that this tends to `Γ(s)` as `n → ∞`.

The norm of a function is controlled by the supremum of the pointwise norms.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : SeminormedAddCommGroup β]
  {f : BoundedContinuousFunction α β} {C : ℝ}, 0 ≤ C → (‖f‖ ≤ C ↔ ∀ (x : α), ‖f x‖ ≤ C)
name: BoundedContinuousFunction.norm_le
docString: The norm of a function is controlled by the supremum of the pointwise norms.

For any natural `k` and a real `r > 1` we have `n ^ k = o(r ^ n)` as `n → ∞`.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_4} [inst : NormedRing R] (k : ℕ) {r : ℝ}, 1 < r → (fun n => ↑n ^ k) =o[Filter.atTop] fun n => r ^ n
name: isLittleO_pow_const_const_pow_of_one_lt
docString: For any natural `k` and a real `r > 1` we have `n ^ k = o(r ^ n)` as `n → ∞`.

Bessel's inequality for finite sums.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : IsROrC 𝕜] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : InnerProductSpace 𝕜 E]
  {ι : Type u_4} (x : E) {v : ι → E} {s : Finset ι},
  Orthonormal 𝕜 v → (Finset.sum s fun i => ‖⟪v i, x⟫_𝕜‖ ^ 2) ≤ ‖x‖ ^ 2
name: Orthonormal.sum_inner_products_le
docString: Bessel's inequality for finite sums.

The product of `f a + g a` over all of `s` is the sum over the powerset of `s` of the product of
`f` over a subset `t` times the product of `g` over the complement of `t`

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {α : Type u_2} [inst : CommSemiring α] [inst_1 : DecidableEq ι] (f g : ι → α) (s : Finset ι),
  (Finset.prod s fun i => f i + g i) =
    Finset.sum (Finset.powerset s) fun t => (Finset.prod t fun i => f i) * Finset.prod (s \ t) fun i => g i
name: Finset.prod_add
docString:
The product of `f a + g a` over all of `s` is the sum over the powerset of `s` of the product of
`f` over a subset `t` times the product of `g` over the complement of `t`

`a ≤ sSup s` for all `a ∈ s`.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_5} [self : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField α] (s : Set α) (a : α), BddAbove s → a ∈ s → a ≤ sSup s
name: ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField.le_csSup
docString: `a ≤ sSup s` for all `a ∈ s`.

The (extended real valued) variation of a function `f` on a set `s` inside a linear order is
the supremum of the sum of `edist (f (u (i+1))) (f (u i))` over all finite increasing
sequences `u` in `s`.

type: {α : Type u_1} → [inst : LinearOrder α] → {E : Type u_2} → [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace E] → (α → E) → Set α → ENNReal
name: eVariationOn
docString:
The (extended real valued) variation of a function `f` on a set `s` inside a linear order is
the supremum of the sum of `edist (f (u (i+1))) (f (u i))` over all finite increasing
sequences `u` in `s`.

Given a (completely) multiplicative function `f : ℕ → F`, where `F` is a normed field,
such that `‖f p‖ < 1` for all primes `p`, we can express the sum of `f n` over all `N`-smooth
positive integers `n` as a product of `(1 - f p)⁻¹` over the primes `p < N`. At the same time,
we show that the sum involved converges absolutely.

type:
∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : NormedField F] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace F] {f : ℕ →* F},
  (∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → ‖f p‖ < 1) →
    ∀ (N : ℕ),
      (Summable fun m => ‖f ↑m‖) ∧ HasSum (fun m => f ↑m) (Finset.prod (Nat.primesBelow N) fun p => (1 - f p)⁻¹)
name: EulerProduct.summable_and_hasSum_smoothNumbers_prod_primesBelow_geometric
docString:
Given a (completely) multiplicative function `f : ℕ → F`, where `F` is a normed field,
such that `‖f p‖ < 1` for all primes `p`, we can express the sum of `f n` over all `N`-smooth
positive integers `n` as a product of `(1 - f p)⁻¹` over the primes `p < N`. At the same time,
we show that the sum involved converges absolutely.

**The second Borel-Cantelli lemma**: Given a sequence of independent sets `(sₙ)` such that
`∑ n, μ sₙ = ∞`, `limsup sₙ` has measure 1.

type:
∀ {Ω : Type u_1} {m0 : MeasurableSpace Ω} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure Ω} [inst : MeasureTheory.IsProbabilityMeasure μ]
  {s : ℕ → Set Ω},
  (∀ (n : ℕ), MeasurableSet (s n)) →
    ProbabilityTheory.iIndepSet s → ∑' (n : ℕ), ↑↑μ (s n) = ⊤ → ↑↑μ (Filter.limsup s Filter.atTop) = 1
name: ProbabilityTheory.measure_limsup_eq_one
docString:
**The second Borel-Cantelli lemma**: Given a sequence of independent sets `(sₙ)` such that
`∑ n, μ sₙ = ∞`, `limsup sₙ` has measure 1.

A `k`-smooth number can be written as a square times a product of distinct primes `< k`.

type: ∀ {n k : ℕ}, n ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers k → ∃ s ∈ Finset.powerset (Nat.primesBelow k), ∃ m, n = m ^ 2 * Finset.prod s id
name: Nat.eq_prod_primes_mul_sq_of_mem_smoothNumbers
docString: A `k`-smooth number can be written as a square times a product of distinct primes `< k`.

The second element of a product $\prod_{i=0}^n (r_i + m_i)$ is a sum of terms of the form
$r_0\cdots r_{i-1}m_ir_{i+1}\cdots r_n$.

type:
∀ {R : Type u} {M : Type v} [inst : Semiring R] [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M] [inst_2 : Module R M]
  [inst_3 : Module Rᵐᵒᵖ M] [inst_4 : SMulCommClass R Rᵐᵒᵖ M] (l : List (TrivSqZeroExt R M)),
  TrivSqZeroExt.snd (List.prod l) =
    List.sum
      (List.map
        (fun x =>
          List.prod (List.take x.1 (List.map TrivSqZeroExt.fst l)) •
            MulOpposite.op (List.prod (List.drop (Nat.succ x.1) (List.map TrivSqZeroExt.fst l))) •
              TrivSqZeroExt.snd x.2)
        (List.enum l))
name: TrivSqZeroExt.snd_list_prod
docString:
The second element of a product $\prod_{i=0}^n (r_i + m_i)$ is a sum of terms of the form
$r_0\cdots r_{i-1}m_ir_{i+1}\cdots r_n$.

The span of a subset `s` is the union over all `n` of the set of linear combinations of at most
`n` terms belonging to `s`.

name: span_eq_iUnion_nat
docString:
The span of a subset `s` is the union over all `n` of the set of linear combinations of at most
`n` terms belonging to `s`.
